items.standfirst: European airports - including London's Heathrow - are warning of delays after a "technical issue" affected check-in and boarding systems.
items.content: European airports - including London's Heathrow - are warning of delays after a "technical issue" affected check-in and boarding systems.

ai_summary: A cyberattack disrupted check-in and boarding systems at several major European airports.
Heathrow, Brussels, and Berlin airports reported significant delays and cancellations due to the attack.
Collins Aerospace, a provider of these systems, confirmed a "cyber-related disruption."
The attack targeted a service provider for check-in and boarding systems.
Some travelers reported multi-hour waits for certain airlines.

clusters.title: Trump to add $100,000 application fee to H-1B foreign worker visas

items.title: Trump to add $100,000 application fee to H-1B foreign worker visas
items.standfirst: Shares in IT consulting groups drop on news of changes to scheme popular with Silicon Valley
items.content: Shares in IT consulting groups drop on news of changes to scheme popular with Silicon Valley

items.title: Trump adds $100,000 fee for skilled worker visa applicants
items.standfirst: "Train Americans," the US commerce secretary told big companies, some of which have relied on foreign high-skilled workers for years.
items.content: "Train Americans," the US commerce secretary told big companies, some of which have relied on foreign high-skilled workers for years.

items.title: Trump raises fee for skilled worker visas by $100,000 despite tech sector warnings
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday ordered the fee for H-1B visas for skilled workers to rise by $100,000 annually despite opposition from the US tech sector, which says it needs skilled foreign workers to fill job vacancies. The US approved about 400,000 H-1B visas in 2024, two-thirds of which were renewals.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday ordered the fee for H-1B visas for skilled workers to rise by $100,000 annually despite opposition from the US tech sector, which says it needs skilled foreign workers to fill job vacancies. The US approved about 400,000 H-1B visas in 2024, two-thirds of which were renewals.

items.title: Trump signs $1M gold card visas, adds $100,000 fee for skilled worker visa applicants
items.standfirst: President Trump signed two executive orders at the White House on Friday night. The first established the Trump Gold Card as a path to U.S. citizenship for $1 million. The second adds a $100,000 fee for skilled worker visas called H-1B worker visas. CBS News reporter Erica Brown has more.
items.content: President Trump signed two executive orders at the White House on Friday night. The first established the Trump Gold Card as a path to U.S. citizenship for $1 million. The second adds a $100,000 fee for skilled worker visas called H-1B worker visas. CBS News reporter Erica Brown has more.

items.title: Trump imposes $100,000 fee per year for H-1B visas
items.standfirst: Fee paid by companies set to transform high-skill work visa system, upon which technology sector relies heavily.
items.content: Fee paid by companies set to transform high-skill work visa system, upon which technology sector relies heavily.

items.title: Donald Trump to introduce $100,000 fees on skilled foreign worker visas
items.standfirst: Donald Trump will introduce a new $100,000 application fee for foreign worker visas.
items.content: Donald Trump will introduce a new $100,000 application fee for foreign worker visas.

ai_summary: President Trump ordered a $100,000 annual fee increase for H-1B visas.
The tech sector, which relies on these visas, opposes the fee increase.
The US approved approximately 400,000 H-1B visas in 2024, mostly renewals.
The fee is intended to transform the high-skill work visa system.
Trump also signed an order establishing a "Trump Gold Card" for $1 million.

items.title: Estonia, NATO slam ‘brazen’ Russian air incursion, Moscow denies claim
items.standfirst: Estonia has accused Russia of breaching its airspace, alleging that three supersonic Russian fighter jets carried out an “unprecedented and brazen” incursion. The accusation, made on Friday, drew swift condemnation from NATO and several European nations, which described the incident as a “reckless” and “dangerous provocation.” Russia’s Ministry of Defence, however, rejected the claim. Simon Moritz has the latest.
items.content: Estonia has accused Russia of breaching its airspace, alleging that three supersonic Russian fighter jets carried out an “unprecedented and brazen” incursion. The accusation, made on Friday, drew swift condemnation from NATO and several European nations, which described the incident as a “reckless” and “dangerous provocation.” Russia’s Ministry of Defence, however, rejected the claim. Simon Moritz has the latest.

items.title: Nato intercepts Russian fighter jets on ‘reckless’ violation of Estonian airspace
items.standfirst: Russia denies what EU calls ‘dangerous provocation’ after Italian air force heads off three MiG-31s over Gulf of FinlandNato has intercepted three Russian MiG-31 fighter jets that violated Estonia’s airspace over the Baltic Sea in a 12-minute incursion, calling it proof of Moscow’s “reckless” behaviour.The EU’s top diplomat, Kaja Kallas, a former Estonian prime minister, accused Moscow of an “extremely dangerous provocation” and said the latest Russian violation of Nato’s eastern borders “further escalates tensions in the region”. Continue reading...

items.title: NATO slams 'reckless' Russian violation of Estonia's airspace
items.standfirst: Three Russian military jets on Friday violated NATO member Estonia's airspace, the latest in a series of recent militaryactions by Russia that have rattled the alliance. NATO has accused Moscow of "reckless behaviour" and Estonia has request urgent NATO talks over the violation of its airspace. FRANCE 24's Dave Keating reports from Brussels.
items.content: Three Russian military jets on Friday violated NATO member Estonia's airspace, the latest in a series of recent militaryactions by Russia that have rattled the alliance. NATO has accused Moscow of "reckless behaviour" and Estonia has request urgent NATO talks over the violation of its airspace. FRANCE 24's Dave Keating reports from Brussels.

items.title: 3 Russian fighter jets violate Estonian airspace in 'brazen' incursion
items.standfirst: Three Russian fighter jets violated Estonian airspace on Friday in a move the Baltic nation called "unprecedentedly brazen," and which appears to be the latest test of NATO's defenses by the Kremlin's forces.
items.content: Three Russian fighter jets violated Estonian airspace on Friday in a move the Baltic nation called "unprecedentedly brazen," and which appears to be the latest test of NATO's defenses by the Kremlin's forces.

ai_summary: Estonia accused Russia of violating its airspace with three fighter jets.
NATO and several European nations condemned the incident as a provocation.
Russia's Ministry of Defence denied the claim of airspace violation.
NATO intercepted the Russian MiG-31 fighter jets over the Baltic Sea.
The EU called the incident a "dangerous provocation" by Russia.

items.title: Trump says US hit another ‘drug vessel’, Venezuela slams ‘undeclared war’
items.standfirst: US president says American forces struck the vessel in the Southern Command's 'area of responsibility', killing three.
items.content: US president says American forces struck the vessel in the Southern Command's 'area of responsibility', killing three.

items.title: Venezuela accuses US of waging 'undeclared war' in strikes on alleged drug traffickers
items.standfirst: Venezuela on Friday accused the United States of waging an “undeclared war” in the Caribbean after a series of US military strikes on boats that the Trump administration says are used in drug trafficking. Venezuela’s Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino Lopez said that those killed in the strikes were “executed without the right to a defense”.
items.content: Venezuela on Friday accused the United States of waging an “undeclared war” in the Caribbean after a series of US military strikes on boats that the Trump administration says are used in drug trafficking. Venezuela’s Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino Lopez said that those killed in the strikes were “executed without the right to a defense”.

ai_summary: The US military conducted a third airstrike targeting alleged drug traffickers.
The strikes occurred in the Caribbean, according to President Trump.
Venezuela condemned the strikes, calling them an "undeclared war."
The US claims the vessels were used for drug trafficking.
Venezuela stated those killed in the strikes were "executed without defense."

clusters.title: Barred from Eurovision, Russia revives Soviet-era rival of beloved song contest
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia's answer to Eurovision is less kitsch, more Kremlin

items.title: Barred from Eurovision, Russia revives Soviet-era rival of beloved song contest
items.standfirst: After it was barred from the Eurovision Song Contest Russia is reviving a Soviet-era version of the camp competition.
items.content: After it was barred from the Eurovision Song Contest Russia is reviving a Soviet-era version of the camp competition.

items.title: Soft power: Russia revives the Intervision song contest, Cold War rival to Eurovision
items.standfirst: Russia on Saturday hosts Intervision, an international song contest that was a regular fixture in Soviet states in the 1960s and ’70s. The revival follows Russia’s exclusion from Eurovision since its full-scale 2022 invasion of Ukraine.
items.content: Russia on Saturday hosts Intervision, an international song contest that was a regular fixture in Soviet states in the 1960s and ’70s. The revival follows Russia’s exclusion from Eurovision since its full-scale 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

items.title: Less camp, more conservative - welcome to Russia's alternative Eurovision
items.standfirst: Banned from Eurovision after its invasion of Ukraine, Russia will hold a rival international song contest on Saturday, with an emphasis on "traditional values".
items.content: Banned from Eurovision after its invasion of Ukraine, Russia will hold a rival international song contest on Saturday, with an emphasis on "traditional values".

items.title: Russia's answer to Eurovision is less kitsch, more Kremlin
items.standfirst: Putin resurrects a Soviet-era global song contest, to distract from Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
items.content: Putin resurrects a Soviet-era global song contest, to distract from Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

ai_summary: Russia, barred from Eurovision, is reviving a Soviet-era song contest.
The revived contest, Intervision, was a Cold War rival to Eurovision.
The new contest emphasizes "traditional values" instead of kitsch.
Russia was excluded from Eurovision after its 2022 invasion of Ukraine.
The contest is seen as a distraction from the invasion of Ukraine.

But…
items.content: ByteDance will proceed with a deal to keep TikTok’s operations in the US in line with “the requirements of Chinese laws”, the social media giant said in a Chinese-language post on WeChat early on Saturday, hours after a call between President Xi Jinping and American counterpart Donald Trump. But…

items.title: Trump: China approved preliminary TikTok deal
items.standfirst: President Trump had a two-hour phone call with China’s leader this afternoon. He said that China has approved a preliminary deal for American ownership of TikTok. NBC News’ Kelly O’Donnell reports.
items.content: President Trump had a two-hour phone call with China’s leader this afternoon. He said that China has approved a preliminary deal for American ownership of TikTok. NBC News’ Kelly O’Donnell reports.

items.content: American leader says Chinese counterpart approved sale of video app’s American operations

items.title: TikTok Deal Has China’s Blessing, Trump Says After Xi Call
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said that his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping had given approval to a sale of TikTok’s US operations to American investors, though he acknowledged that some final steps still need to be worked out.
items.content: President Donald Trump said that his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping had given approval to a sale of TikTok’s US operations to American investors, though he acknowledged that some final steps still need to be worked out.

items.title: Trump says call with China's Xi on TikTok was 'productive' and he plans to visit China next year
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump is set to speak with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on Friday as they try to finalize a deal to keep the popular short-video app TikTok operating in the United States.
items.content: President Donald Trump is set to speak with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on Friday as they try to finalize a deal to keep the popular short-video app TikTok operating in the United States.

items.title: Trump, Xi Call Underway as They Aim to Finalize TikTok Deal
items.standfirst: A call between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping is underway, in a discussion that promises to determine the fate of TikTok — and potentially ease trade tensions between the world’s two biggest economies.
items.content: A call between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping is underway, in a discussion that promises to determine the fate of TikTok — and potentially ease trade tensions between the world’s two biggest economies.

ai_summary: President Trump said China approved a preliminary TikTok deal.
The deal involves American ownership of TikTok's US operations.
Trump and Xi Jinping had a two-hour phone call to discuss the deal.
Final steps of the deal still need to be worked out.
The call aimed to finalize the deal and ease trade tensions.

items.title: Attorney investigating Trump critics resigns after pressure from officials – as it happened
items.standfirst: Trump said ‘I want him out’ about Erik Siebert, who was investigating New York attorney general Letitia James and former FBI director James Comey. This blog is now closed.Today, lawmakers in the House will vote on legislation, known as a “continuing resolution” (CR), to prevent a looming government shutdown at the end of September.The bill, introduced by Republicans, would fund the government until 21 November. According to Politico, House GOP whip Tom Emmer was confident, as of Thursday, that his party had enough votes. “We’re going to pass this,” he said in an interview. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump said ‘I want him out’ about Erik Siebert, who was investigating New York attorney general Letitia James and former FBI director James Comey. This blog is now closed.Today, lawmakers in the House will vote on legislation, known as a “continuing resolution” (CR), to prevent a looming government shutdown at the end of September.The bill, introduced by Republicans, would fund the government until 21 November. According to Politico, House GOP whip Tom Emmer was confident, as of Thursday, that his party had enough votes. “We’re going to pass this,” he said in an interview. Continue reading...

items.title: Acting U.S. attorney resigns amid concern he could be fired for not prosecuting NY AG
items.standfirst: In April, a Trump ally referred New York Attorney General Letitia James for federal criminal prosecution for alleged mortgage fraud.
items.content: In April, a Trump ally referred New York Attorney General Letitia James for federal criminal prosecution for alleged mortgage fraud.

items.title: US attorney tasked with inquiring into Trump critics resigns after president says ‘I want him out’
items.standfirst: Erik Siebert leaving after his investigation finds insufficient evidence to charge New York’s attorney general Letitia James with a crimeThe federal prosecutor for the eastern district of Virginia resigned Friday under intense pressure from Donald Trump, after his office determined there wasn’t sufficient evidence to charge New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, a political rival of the president, with a crime.Erik Siebert told colleagues he was resigning in a letter sent Friday, NBC News reported. Hours earlier, Trump bluntly told reporters in the Oval Office: “I want him out.” The president claimed he soured on Siebert because Virginia’s two Democratic senators had endorsed his nomination, but also claimed that James “is very guilty of something”. ABC News reported earlier on Friday that Trump decided to fire Siebert after he failed to obtain an indictment against James. Continue reading...
items.content: Erik Siebert leaving after his investigation finds insufficient evidence to charge New York’s attorney general Letitia James with a crimeThe federal prosecutor for the eastern district of Virginia resigned Friday under intense pressure from Donald Trump, after his office determined there wasn’t sufficient evidence to charge New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, a political rival of the president, with a crime.Erik Siebert told colleagues he was resigning in a letter sent Friday, NBC News reported. Hours earlier, Trump bluntly told reporters in the Oval Office: “I want him out.” The president claimed he soured on Siebert because Virginia’s two Democratic senators had endorsed his nomination, but also claimed that James “is very guilty of something”. ABC News reported earlier on Friday that Trump decided to fire Siebert after he failed to obtain an indictment against James. Continue reading...

ai_summary: U.S. Attorney Erik Siebert resigned after refusing to pursue a case.
He refused to pursue a criminal case against NY AG Letitia James.
Trump reportedly wanted Siebert to investigate James.
Siebert's investigation found insufficient evidence to charge James.
Siebert was investigating other Trump critics as well.

items.title: Trump again asks supreme court to end protections for Venezuelans in US
items.standfirst: Justice department urges court to overturn ruling that Kristi Noem lacked authority to end TPS programThe Trump administration asked the US supreme court on Friday to intervene for the second time in a case involving its bid to end deportation protections the former president, Joe Biden, granted to hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans in the United States.The justice department filed an emergency application asking the justices to lift a federal judge’s ruling that the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, lacked the authority to end the protections for Venezuelans under the temporary protected status, or TPS, program. Continue reading...
items.content: Justice department urges court to overturn ruling that Kristi Noem lacked authority to end TPS programThe Trump administration asked the US supreme court on Friday to intervene for the second time in a case involving its bid to end deportation protections the former president, Joe Biden, granted to hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans in the United States.The justice department filed an emergency application asking the justices to lift a federal judge’s ruling that the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, lacked the authority to end the protections for Venezuelans under the temporary protected status, or TPS, program. Continue reading...

items.title: Judges rule against Trump administration on deporting Guatemalan children and Venezuelans
items.standfirst: Double defeat protects Venezuelans with temporary protected status and Guatemalan minorsThe Trump administration has been handed a double defeat by judges in immigration cases, barring the executive branch from deporting a group of Guatemalan children and from slashing protections for many Venezuelans in the US.A federal judge on Thursday ordered the administration to refrain from deporting Guatemalan unaccompanied immigrant children with active immigration cases while a legal challenge plays out. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
